title: Harmonic Sum
content: The harmonic sum of a set A is Σ_{n ∈ A} 1/n. This is the sum of unit fractions (Egyptian fractions) for elements in A.

title: Egyptian Representation
content: A set A ⊆ {1,...,N} is an Egyptian representation if its harmonic sum equals 1 and all elements are positive.

title: Egyptian Count Function
content: egyptianCount(N) counts subsets of {1,...,N} whose harmonic sum equals exactly 1. This is the central object of the problem.

title: Subexponential Growth Question
content: The key question: is there c < 1 with egyptianCount(N) ≤ 2^{cN}? This asks whether the count is exponentially smaller than the total 2^N subsets.

title: Steinerberger's Upper Bound (2024)
content: Steinerberger proved egyptianCount(N) ≤ 2^{0.93N} for large N. This was the first rigorous proof that c < 1.

title: Liu-Sawhney Constant
content: The optimal constant c ≈ 0.91... is defined as the solution to a certain integral equation. It lies between 0.9 and 0.92.

title: Liu-Sawhney Full Asymptotic (2024)
content: Liu-Sawhney proved the complete asymptotic: egyptianCount(N) = 2^{(c+o(1))N} where c ≈ 0.91... is their constant.

title: Conlon et al. Generalization (2024)
content: Conlon-Fox-He-Mubayi-Pham-Suk-Verstraëte proved the same asymptotic independently and generalized to arbitrary rational targets x > 0.

title: Why c < 1
content: Most subsets overshoot 1 because the expected sum of a random subset is ~(log N)/2 which grows without bound. The constraint of sum exactly equal to 1 is very restrictive.

title: Main Theorem
content: The count of A ⊆ {1,...,N} with Σ 1/n = 1 is 2^{(c+o(1))N} where 0.9 < c < 0.93 (the Liu-Sawhney constant).

title: Erdős's Question Answered
content: YES, the count has subexponential growth: egyptianCount(N) = 2^{cN} for c < 1. This follows from Steinerberger's upper bound.
